content:
ry 23, 2016
												They should just sell this game like a normal game. It's not f2p.Got to level 11, grinded for like 2 hours to get the next level, and realized I wasn't getting any exp. It capped at lvl 11. Gotta pay to progress.Saved up some cash in an attempt to get some of the more valuable armor (which is terribly expensive), only to see that any money I made was being tranferred to an online "bank" that could only be accessed by paying to be premium. Capped at $1,500, which is about enough to get a soda. Literally. Gotta pay to...have money.Wanted to go to battle in a quest only to find out I didn't have a high enough combat rating. You need to have a high enough combat rating to even play quests, so this requires you to buy really expensive armor. At some point, I imagine there will only be a select few armor pieces that will get your CR high enough to play late quests, which very much limits what you will be able to wear. I can envision a team of 4 all wearing the same thing even though they'd rather wear something else. What this all means is that you have no choice but to pay $. You're required to have great armor, and can't afford it cuz of the whole temporary robbery system (online pay-only bank). To get the armor, you need the money, which caps at $1,500, yet what you'll need will cost like $75,000+, so it's impossible. Even if you had the money, you'd need separate "badges" earned from completing quests, and lots of them. Lots of reasons you need $. Gotta pay.I tried to collect Hearts for the Valentine's Day events. Complete certain quests, get Hearts. However, you can only complete each once, and need to spend Replay Badges to replay them. So, this is achieved through quests as well, but you won't have done enough to have multiple Replay Badges, so you won't be able to aquire enough Hearts to get anything you want. Gotta pay to get Replay Badges.I was collecting a lot of stuff, and soon ran out of inventory space. Yep, you have limited inventory space, and find things everywhere, all cluttering your inventory. The Bank where you store your excess stuff has its own limitations as well. You'll run out of room quickly, and selling things off only sends money to your online bank, which can't be accessed. Gotta pay to keep your own money?I went through a lot of work to create an armor mod. Need to collect Exobits to create an Exobyte, which then requires another item to combine with it to make a mod. I realized I couldn't even equip it because the 4 mod slots are Locked. Gotta pay.Everything in the game gets impeded by paywalls. There's no way to progress in any meaningful way in this game without spending money. Like I said, they should just sell this as a normal game.You can create 2 characters. I recommend making a hero and a villain. If you want to make more, you gotta pay. You have different movement and fighting styles. These are limited, though. If you want access to them all, you gotta pay. In fact, I'd say they managed to put a paywall on just about everything in the game.Pay To Play.Good:The game itself is pretty cool. Cool combos, cool abilities, you can fly, decent character customization, fun city with many enemy types, and a lot of different abilities, which have their own limits, due to the level cap. Decent fanfare, with known enemies being the bosses, and your hero of choice backing you up. It's always cool to get a call from Batman. :)Bad:Pay money or don't bother playing. Everything you need is locked behind paywalls. Voice acting is bad, and you don't really have the freedom to wear what you want into battle, due to the combat rating system. Everything seems too expensive, even with in-game money. You'll need to grind like crazy.Be ready to get out your credit card, or don't download this game. There's more freedom even in ArcheAge than this game. I've heard Champions Online is actually f2p, so I'd say play that instead, unless you're prepared to pay. I was actually considering buying some stuff, but when I realized how much they locked away and how far they went to mandate cash payments to get anywhere in this game, I decided it wasn't worth giving them money afterall.FieldRatingGraphics:5/10Controls:8/10Functionality:7/10Fun:6/10Replay value:?/10Overall:6.5/10That rates the game, but I would just love to knock off like 2 points for gouging our wallets so blatantly, and then having the nerve to call this a f2p game. It's a fun game and all, but advertised incorrectly. Just way too many limitations to enjoy without buying all the game's content. This is a demo, nothing more. I recommend it only to those who have come prepared to buy the game. If you were hoping to have a fun adventure, or to go PvP or co-op with friends, you had better get that credit card ready. Nothing free here.

content:
3, 2014
												A while back I heard this game wasn't worth bothering with. I can't remember who told me that, but they were either full of ♥♥♥♥, or the game has undergone some massive improvements since said person played it. Previously, my favorite superhero game was Champions online, and while DC Universe Online has significantly less customization features than champions, everything else seems to be improved greatly. First lets get the cons out of the way.Don't get me wrong, DCUO has some excellent character customization, and I was able to create several characters that somewhat fit the image I had for them when I began to create them, and it's important to keep in mind that there are more "styles" you can discover as you play through the game that are not available from the character creator that can be changed even after character creation, similarly to Champions. However, unlike Champions, there are several aspects of your character that are locked after the character creation, such as your character's body type, stance, power set, travel power, and skin type.Another minor gripe i have with DCUO is the size of the world. Normally for me this would be a big problem, but there are many DLC packs that expand upon the world, one of which even adding brand new city. For free players the game almost exclusively takes place in Gotham City and Metropolis, with some alerts (dungeons) taking place in other places such as area 51, and another on the moon. I don't currently plan to buy all the DLCs due to my situation for money, but i'm considering maybe slowly purchasing the DLCs over time.the last problem I have with the game is that unless you are subscribed, at $15 a month, your currency will be capped at $2000 which makes the auction broker unusable at level 30 unless you subscribe as everything for sale is over $2000.With the complaints out of the way, lets get to why I love this game.1. The Combat:One of the biggest things that turned me off to champions online was the combat. It used the stale system made popular by WoW of tab targetting to who you wanted to attack and pressing a button until it dies. In DCUO there is a soft targetting system similar to the Elder Scrolls Online, where you will target whoever is closest, both to the center of your screen and to your character, with the ability to lock your target if you needed to focus on a highly mobile target, which is very helpful for ranged characters. You must block heavy attacks that most enemies will attempt to stun you with, and there is the ability for all power/weapon sets to dodge, but this is more useful for escaping aoe attacks than for anything else. The weapon you choose will determine what combos you have with your mouse clicks, with all weapons sharing a control scheme in common with left click being a light melee attack, left hold being a heavy ranged interrupt, right click being a light ranged attack, and right hold being a heavy ranged block breaker (that can still be used in melee distance)If you fail to block an enemy's heavy attack, or an enemy blocks your attack, you will be stunned momentarily, this can be broken out of at the cost of some energy using the block button.meanwhile your power sets determine some of your heaviest hitting abilities, unlike weapon combos, these abilities cost energy to use, making weapon combos still highly viable over abilities as they cost no energy to use. This, in my opinion, creates a fantastic balance between powers and weapons, making you want to use both in equal measure instead of spamming one button until an enemy dies.2. Improved Travel Powers:While i will admit Champions online has a HUGE selection of travel powers to choose from than DCUO, the travel powers in DCUO are much more interesting to use, and unlike champions, also come with their own seperate skill trees. You can choose from either flight, superspeed, or acrobatics. In flight...well...you can fly, but unlike champions your character has momentum while flying through the air, making much smoother turns, and providing a challenge to some of the flight challenges found in the city, also if you fly down towards the ground your character will gain a speed boost, which, with some points spent in the flight skill tree, can be used as an opening attack in a fight. the first skill in the flight skill tree also gives the user the ability to fly in any direction with the speed normally given by diving towards the ground at the cost of a reduced mouse sensitivity, making it much harder to turn.I haven't tried superspeed so i can't tell you what makes it special, but i see plenty of people using it so it must be as fun as the others.Acrobatics in champions gave you improved run speed, that was less than superspeed but gave you the ability to jump higher. in DCUO acrobatics doesn't make your jump go higher, but provides a double jump instead, which makes it feel more involved, in addition it comes with a glide ability that works similarly to the gliding mechanic in prototype, and the ability to climb up walls as well, with points spent in the acrobatics tree 2 additions are made to it, holding the glide button while in range of a wall will launch a grappling hook to reel you into it quickly, and doing the same while climbing a wall will make you grapple up to the top at an incredible speed. While acrobatics at a low level is the slowest power, the grappling mechanic gives it the highest potential for speed for those with the talent to do so.3. Narration:In Champions online, there were of course a couple cutscenes, some of which were voiced, but for the most part the quests worked like they did back in vanilla WoW. you talk to several NPCs, some text tells you to go kill 10 mobs and return to them. In DCUO, the entire story is narrated, sometimes by oracle (for heroes) or calculator (for villains), and other times by one of the 3 mentor heroes or villains you can choose at the start of the game, such as batman, superman, wonderwoman, and for villains, the Joker, Lex Luthor, and Circe.Through my time playing so far, i have not once been asked to turn in a quest at an NPC, as all quest rewards can be collected directly from your quest journal, which will automatically assign the next quest in the mini story.4. The Skill Trees:While champions online had excellent ability customization for freeform characters, it got a little confusing when trying to level up your skills. While i dislike that the powers do not give the same freedom of customization as the weapon skills do, the interface for leveling up both weapons and powers is a huge improvement from champions. There are no trainers, and instead every time you level up you get a point to spend in powers and/or weapons, for each power set there are two styles to choose from, and once you reach level 10 you can also choose from a third tree that includes "iconic powers" such as superman's heat vision and frost breath. Or even a baterang volley.TLDR version:This game has its flaws, but it makes up for it and overall is a highly enjoyable game i would recomend to anyone who at least mildly enjoys superheroes

												DCUO is a great superhero MMO. that being said, its the only one currently out there. balance is bad. lower tiers can be harder than higher tiers. this game uses marks to buy gear, and when you progress, you can no longer earn marks from instances in lower tiers. combat is fun, but repetitive. character builds dont vary too much at all. creating characters with many different powers and having a league hall and your own personal lair--all these are fun. maybe wait until they fix the problems created with "rebalancing". overall, i recommend the game. expect to pay about $10 per episode (after tier 3, about 2-3 episodes per tier) or buy the episode packs. if you are a comic book nerd, you will love it, but be prepared to put up with a lot of seriously dumb design decisions.

content:
y 27, 2014
												A few years ago in the town of Middlebury Oregon, there was a man named Joseph Woodstock. He liked to be called Joey. He was a nice fellow, with a few close friends. The local ladies who saw him sometimes bowling at the local Bowl-o-Rama Bowling Alley said he was pleasant on the eyes. He was a nice guy to be around, and a very pleasant conversationalist. He knew all the right things to say, and never seemed to be on anyone's bad side. He never had a run in the with local police, and was very straight and narrow. He owned an auto parts store in town. the shop being one of only 2 auto places in town was profitable, leaving Joey to skip the 9 to 5 grind, and have plenty of free time to pursue more leisurly activities. Joey was American as apple pie, and loving life to the fullest. He did have a girlfriend, whom he had even asked to marry him recently. She gladly accepted. Joey's life seemed set. Joey was a good wholesome average man, with lots to live for. Which is why none of the rest of this makes sense...On the night of September 14th, 2012, Joey was last seen sitting outside of his 2 story home, on his steps. A neighbor recalls seeing Joey through her window across the street. Joey appeared to be shaking, wearing only what appeared to be a towel, shorts (possibly boxers), and no shoes on. He looked a mess. The neighbor went downstairs, and when she went out of her door to see if Joey was okay, he was gone. She went to his front door and rang the doorbell, but there was no answer. 2 days later, Joey's body was found outside of town washed up in a riverbed. Police say there was no signs of foul play, and it appeared that he had commited suicide by jumping off a bridge located further upstream, breaking his neck on impact. None of this made sense. This man, whom was recently engaged and not in any trouble financially or otherwise, took his own life? This made no sense at all.Police searched his home and found no evidence of foul play. When they searched his den, the lights were flickering off and on, with a faint humming coming from a computer fan. The computer had been left on. Maybe there were clues here? One officer walked up to the computer desk, and touched the mouse enough to get the computer out of sleep mode. what he saw haunted him. A few seconds later, the computer monitor sparked, and then it shut off. It had died. As well as the computer with it. Haunted by what he had seen, officer Henry King mentioned none of this to other officers, and left what he had seen on the screen out of his report. 4 days later, Henry King was found dead in his apartment. He had hung himself the night before. On his computer monitor it flickered off and on. DC Universe™ Online Free-To-Play. Your Way®. 												A few years ago in the town of Middlebury Oregon, there was a man named Joseph Woodstock. He liked to be called Joey. He was a nice fellow, with a few close friends. The local ladies who saw him sometimes bowling at the local Bowl-o-Rama Bowling Alley said he was pleasant on the eyes. He was a nice guy to be around, and a very pleasant conversationalist. He knew all the right things to say, and never seemed to be on anyone's bad side. He never had a run in the with local police, and was very straight and narrow. He owned an auto parts store in town. the shop being one of only 2 auto places in town was profitable, leaving Joey to skip the 9 to 5 grind, and have plenty of free time to pursue more leisurly activities. Joey was American as apple pie, and loving life to the fullest. He did have a girlfriend, whom he had even asked to marry him recently. She gladly accepted. Joey's life seemed set. Joey was a good wholesome average man, with lots to live for. content:
, 2016
												I played this a lot on the playstation and computer. I have way more hours than what steam suggests. However; I did not enjoy the game anymore a couple years back. Coming back I expected the same old introduction, and tired ♥♥♥ quests, that I had already completed. Instead, they acknowledged the age of the game and told a story of the humans failure. They also made it to where as long as you tag a enemy or objective, you will get it, so first hitting mobs doesn't matter as the quests are completed with area based people. The playerbase does a fairly good job in low levels to prevent people from farming lowbies. A lot of people seem to have an issue with daybreak, but I find them to be great, and very helpful. This is a free to play game, but those who complain are the same people who do not support the game. This is a company and they need funding to continue gaming. Not too mention, I also played Planetside 2 as well. Daybreak has a 5 game pass for the price of one mmo. Now I hate Everquest, EQ 2 and Landmark. However; I suggest you play until level 30, if you do decide prior to that to subscribe great...but once you reach 30 on your main, I would suggest obtaining the benefits of a subscription if you are able to afford it. The story feels fresh again, although the quests are the same until you get to newer content. The graphics have been polished fairly well, and the gameplay is still one of the best out there.  If you are thinking about playing it for the first time, I would suggest doing so until at least level 30, so you can finish the first storyline. It is ftp afterall and the not having the benefits is not going to cripple you early. You can farm a lot for the gear and items you need and/or want. However; the subscription is a convenience, it is not required, but once you start grinding for gear to PVP or whatever you enjoy, it will take you longer.

content:
12
												Plenty of games experience controversy in the same way that any entertainment medium does, but the drama surrounding this one is a real doozy.Ignoring all of that, I can say that in my near 3000 hours of playing this (not even counting the time I played the game outside of Steam or time spent on the test server), I have enjoyed most of it. Started playing the game in 2012, played consistently through 2016 and have only played off and on as of late, so my perception of the game may differ from when you may be reading this review, but I don't regret the amount of time I've put into it.Short version: I recommend the game for any superhero fan or anyone looking to kill a few hours with mind numbing action RPG entertainment without paying a cent.Long version: I'm going to have to break this down a bit.* Free-To-Play Friendliness - You can play all the way to the base level cap of 30 without paying a dime. The cash cap imposed on F2P players is pretty irrelevant for the main "campaign" so to speak of the game. You only need to spend in game currency to buy consumable healing items or repair you gear in this portion of the game, and your income will be pretty steady as you constantly get new gear to replace your current gear and can sell it to cover the aforementioned costs. The amount of content you can play extends through the third tier of endgame content, after which you'll need to either buy DLCs or subscribe to continue progressing. But if you're still playing the game by that point, you're probably invested enough to know whether you want to drop real world money or not.* The community - This game's community gets pretty toxic pretty fast. I highly recommend disabling the zone "Shout" chat as soon as you get into the game. It's essentially nothing but kids and man-children trash talking each other's PVP ability and making childish insults about sexuality and mothers. People in multiplayer instanced content come in three flavors... two being more common than the other one. The first and largest group are the people who will say nothing at all. No voice chat, no text chat. They'll play and they'll leave as though they are computer controlled bots. Then, you get the toxic bunch that I mentioned earlier who will try to dictate how everyone will play and will vote kick those who don't conform. And lastly, and unfortunately most rarely, you get easygoing fun people who will chat and joke and play the game for the express purpose of having fun. So be prepared to gamble when you play content post-level 30.* Combat - In a constant state of flux. Patches are applied on the regular to reshuffle the balance of different superpower sets and their ability to do damage as well as their role playing role. F2P players will be happy to know that the free powers are consistently among the top performers with Ice, Mental, and Sorcery being high damagers, Ice also being one of the best tanks, and Nature being hailed as the strongest healing power. However, be warned that a total rework of all powers is going on right now and the way combat works is being renovated for impending release any month now.The combat itself is fairly interesting for an MMO. It's very reminiscent of beat-em-ups superhero game fans will be familiar with. Some rock-paper-scissor elements add a tinge of skill to it and some classic MMORPG RNG comes in and wipes a bit of that skill away. But overall, I've had fun with the combat both in PVE and my limited PVP experience and have even found it addicting in the early days.* Lore - DC fans will gush over all of the references hidden throughout the game's storylines and open world locations. Things have a tendency to skew Lantern Corps and Amazonian heavy in the later game, but Superman fans have a trilogy of phenomenal raids to look forward to, Flash fans get a lot of love in a major story arc at endgame, and Batman fans have nothing to worry about either. Justice Society, Teen Titans, New Gods, and mystical/magical fans get a few scraps thrown their way here and there as well. So if you're riding a high from watching a new episode of the CW shows or somehow find enjoyment in the DCEU movie offerings, you'll get to ride it a little longer through playing this game.There are so many other things I could touch on, but I'm not trying to write a novel here. I thumbed this up out of nostalgia for the good times I've had with this game over the past 5 or so years, but it's by no means perfect and definitely isn't recommended for everyone. The best way to approach this one is to give it a try for free and decide after a couple of hours if it's worth your time to continue.

content:
ber 25, 2016
												The time up to lvl 30 can be fun, but forget about doing any of the "alerts" if you want to actually play the game. Same at level 30, all the alerts and raids are just watching people way over lvl'd speed run thru. Stuff will be dead before you even get to the rooms half the time, and sure you get loot drops etc, you'll have no idea how to play because this will be the next month or two of not playing and just watching speed runs.The endgame mechanics are pretty awful, as 30 is the lvl cap, but then you have combat rating, or CR as they call it. Which is like a secondary lvl mechanic. That will change soon however and their going to a stat based system, how is apparently use to be. You raise those by equipment, and with skillpoints. How do you gain skillpoints? Feats, which are essentially what everyone else calls achievements. So between your monthly raid locks, you get to go run around doing dumb stuff for the feats. Like what, you may ask? Like speed running thru the lower level alerts & raids. Yup.. the game actually promotes that.If you're a big fan of DC, it couldn't hurt to try a free trial, but I wouldn't waste money on it til you get to lvl 30 (it won't take long at all, trust me) and see what you think of the "end game." If talking in chat while waiting for alerts & raids, so you can do more of nothing while people speed run it, but still get fancy loot you'll never actually use sounds like fun to you, then maybe think about throwing money at them.

ber 30, 2016
												An MMO, to me, is about the massively multiplayer aspect. If it's just a single player game in a multiplayer universe then I really don't see the point. This game is neither and both, it's a single player game and it's a multiplayer game, but for me the multiplayer side just didn't work.The first group instance is pretty good, but I noticed a problem straight away as a Level 60-something joined in with the Level 10-ish's and steamrolled the content, meaning the rest of us might as well have not been there. Later I noticed nobody changed their roles, everyone stuck to Damage instead of setting up as Tank/Healer/Controller, so people died over and over like some weird zerg against the enemy. Finally, the later group instances are just ridiculous for lower levels. The one I went into was blue level 12 for me at level 15 and as soon as anything so much as looked at me, I was dead in a couple of seconds. This was made worse by the fact that everyone was staying Damage, so there was no Tank to draw the fire. The only option was to follow the inevitable level 50-something around and pick up the loot and xp as you went.Totally pointless multiplayer game. The solo game is kinda boring and repetitive. For me, not recommended.

content:
9, 2014
												Would not recommend this game by far 7200 hours on this game in 4 years ( toooo much time ).  The bad out weighs  the good seeing how the good is slowing being destroyed by a money ran dev team. The Good: Movement options are great since they give you various options to gank/ enter battles. Acro was my got to for everything but tanking since the skills you can learn weren't meant for it unless you want to power single target pulls; to it's credit the super move is good for tanking. Flight is a cheap way to find collectables and beat everyone not experienced in superspeed and superspeed is good for speedruns with experience. The combat is superb, 3rd person perspective getting the chance to admire your nude cowboy Rage Dps while they chain whip things. Controls were meant for a controller considering a port from the PS, If your gonna use keyboard make sure you know it because 1-+ will be used on a norm at fast paces considering your dlc ownership. Character creation is good, not great because you need dlcs to make your character truely have options. You can Lock your suit in if you like your starter character or change it while your not in combat anywhere in game.The Bad:The company wants your money period JENS said it on a stream, since Amazon Fury came out the content is now noticeably reused and called new. Dlc is $10 and can only be used with cash and they made being a member damn near needed since free players have limited broker usage, have a 1.5k spending limit and can't trade (haven't stayed free long enough to get all the info). Premium players 14 extra Inventory slots-12 extra Bank slots-4 extra Character slots-Ability to Trade Items with other players-$2k spending limit-Proximity chat-Vault access every 3 day. This game has the ftp model try before you buy, Soe doesn't want server space being used for non-paying customers, if i was wrong they wouldn't have the ridiculous limitations on this game. Community: if your lucky you'll find friends to carry you being anything but legendary. Premiums get a pass only if you have participating dlcs. Pvp is a travesty of High lvls/Cr pounding lowbies, being a new player you won't have the experience to tackle the cr/stat challenge. High skilled/ can strip all their gear off and beat a rush to t6 pvp players everyone else is just roaches waiting to be squashed. The amount of MMOOK spam in chat is f*cked up, ignoring them is a option but they're like a Horrible Joke, once you think they're gone; they're back again (MMOOK is a spam site trying to trade ingame cash for real cash). Ask yourself, is the game worth spending money on? The necessary $5 to spend to avoid FTP could be put somewhere else,something more constructive (buying an animal would be more constructive than DCUO). By next year, they will re-release content for full price with "incentives" because they won't need to create anything new/;the dedicated players/new players will eat it up with all the nerfs and rehashed crap.

content:
, 2016
												I can honestly say after playing this game for over 600 logged hours through steam, I can honestly say this is a fun, and unique game. Yes there can be grinding, and yes you are limited by free to play. Premium is a little better which I am now, owning only a few DLC's  packs, styles etc. Then there is Membership which has its perks, and is nice, but in my opinion not needed for fun. I bounce from premium, to member on and off, depending on how much time i wanna put in that particular month. If you are free to play you only get two character slots, but you can delete, and make new characters if you are into going a different path with a character. Premium you get six slots which is better, and of course membership you get more. Either way its a fun game, and I recommend especially if you are big DC Comic fan such as myself.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
10, 2016
												Look at the time i played the game, says much...Main reason: I played that game back then( 3 years ago) because it was hard, you will never find any other game, that will have the same difficulty as this game had (the dificulty came from the mechanics of this game, it was not a question about gear, but your own personal skills (think of "dark souls")), therefore it was a challenge, it made me search for a good guild and find friends, if you wanted to play solo... forget it, thats what i liked. good guilds formed and competed with each other, everyone wanted to be the first and the best, and to acomplish it, you just needed your personal skills, no grinding for best gear, no p2w, only subscribe to play. Other reasons: Unique combat which was revolutionary when this game released, and still, until now i didnt find any other MMO where the combat is better or even the same. The best part about combat is, that you not only push your buttons and wait for the boss to die, the game asks you to do something special while fighting, so you have to interrupt combat. this way every single fight becomes unique and requires its own tactics. this feature is also unique, there is no other game that has it.This game is simple, there is not much crafting like in other mmos, no gathering 100 different types of materials, no upgrading gear to +20, no special bonusses on gear, which you have to study to understand and pay incredible amount of money to buy from other players to get or spend incredible amount of time grinding dungeons and hope it drops and what not all those WoW inspired MMOs have. because of this, this game has to provide hard content, where players fail and spend time trying to finish it, otherwise there would be not much to do, and it worked well back then, butthe dificulty was so high, that many ppl complained, that they could not finish content, because they lack personal skill and are unable to play as team and use tactics, so the devs desided to lower the dificulty and make it basically a brainAFK grindy game and every 3d month they release another content to grind, all players, who played this because of the high difficulty left and the game turned into a ghosttown, now the game slowly filles with players, because other players start to play who is ok with all the grinding, So if you are OK with brainAFK playstyle then definetly go for it, you will see a masterpiece of a MMO.earlyer i would have given it a YES, but because this game right now is nothing but a huge grind (in the end game), i will give it a no.

content:
er 15, 2016
												★★☆☆☆This barely DC themed MMO plays like a bad console port, which is epsecially strange for an MMO.+ Once collected, you can freely change between equipments to customize the look of your costume+- Cool intro cinematic, too bad its nothing like the actual game+- Weird weapon/power combos.  Dual wield pistols, with ice powers, and flight.- Unresponsive controls- Standard MMO "kill 10 bear" quests- Menus are designed for controller use- SoE soldout to Daybreak after H1Z1 scams- FPS drops, Audio stuttering, Connectivity issues- Pay2fun, too much of this game is locked behind paywalls- Weird combo based combat, tap LMB twice, then hold it, meh- Doesn't feel like a superhero game, no less a DC specific one- Default running animation, reminds me of Adam West's Batman- After some sort of server-merge, my character's name was ruined- The settings button in the launcher brings up an infinite crash loop in .net- Very few graphic options, No borderless window option, Vsync caps the game at 30 FPS- Default character customization is almost pointless, as equipment changes your costume- Weird loadout system, which gives your powers different modifiers, as you change minor roles- Weak DC theme, there are occasionally misisons where you team up with DC heroes, but they are few and far between.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 4, 2014
												This may be the perfect game for you!If you like:- Unskippable voice acting cutscenes in 2014 (BOOSTER, STFU - it was funny the first 10 times),- Clearly-designed-for-console games on PC that still feel like console games,- Crafting material collection game mechanics that allows other players to steal your drops (this is 100% true),- An ingame community who use words that would make CoD multiplay gamers blush,- Badly written storylines in which DC characters will act out of character (these are pretty rare though),- DLC which consists mostly of game areas which can only be accessed by teams, and 'new power types' which are clearly mostly reskins/cookie-cutter-trash.- Did I mention the utterly crappy crafting material collection mechanic, which allows other players to steal your drops?,- Decent voice acting (seriously, it's mostly pretty good - even if you can't skip some of it),- Skill/power trees with so much planned redundancy that it would make a 90s game shake its head in pity,- An endgame that is so grindy that it would make most Korean game companies shake their head in disgust,- And also if I haven't mentioned it yet, the extremely poorly designed crafting material collection mechanics?- Getting a stipend when you sub - but only if you got to the DCUO website and collect it. NOWHERE was this explained.- if you liked Champions Online, but thought it was way too complicated, then this may just be the game for you.I spent just over 600 hours in-game. I must have spent at least 1/4-5 of those trying to collect crafting mats.  Over the space of a few years, obviously - every 4-5 play sessions, I would stupidly dedicate to trying to collect crafting mats, and then get angry and quit the game for weeks, then start the whole cycle all over again upon my return. Did I mention how devoid of logic and fairness that the crafting material collection mechanics are? I cannot stress this enough - it makes Elder Scrolls Online look like a hippie commune in comparison. Oh, it's okay because you can buy something for real money that will show you where they are. But this STILL doesn't protect you from having your mats interfered with by other players, so why bother?You go up to the thing, and press 'Use'. If anyone else comes up after you, they can interrupt your gathering attempt, and start their own. And then you interrupt theirs. Whoever had the best internet connection will win. So, whoever lives the closest to a city in real life will win. This would be acceptable on a PvP server. This is not acceptable, in 2014, on a PvE server. Maybe they've changed it since. I don't care. I fail to see how that magically returns the many hours I wasted trying to get crafting materials.Free-To-Play, MY way? No. Not even remotely.MY way would have asynchronous crafting mat collection, or would make it so that whoever was first there would get the drop.Why am I going on about this? Because this is one of those games where you can't do the end-content unless you get the kick*** gear (I don't mean it's harder without it, I mean that it won't let you click on the mission to start it) , and you can't get the kick*** gear without crafting, or buying for an extremely unreasonable price on the market. Let me make this clear - the crafting mats collection mechanics could, in all likelihood, STOP you from accessing content that you've PAID REAL LIFE MONEY FOR. It sure did in my case.Free-To-Play, MY way? No. Nope. Not even close. What a joke.So why am I STILL recommending this game, even though I clearly hate it and everything about it?PURELY because it basically ignores the whole New52 thing.Some of the characters might act in ways that don't make sense (Robin is an idiot in this game, even if his voice acting is great) - but at least the Joker has an actual face, and Supermans costume doesn't look like a set of longjohns with a fannypack.In conclusion, this is the easily greatest singleplayer superhero game never made.

content:
11, 2016
												Cons: The premise: A thrown away game in a thrown away version of a thrown away continuity. The Gameplay: A console MMO poorly ported to Windows. So badly so that the use of simple macros and a programmable keyboard, mouse or game controller has allowed the game's PvE and moreso PvP to be dominated by cheaters and sploiters. Ancient bugs and issues that have not been even addresses since launch. Pay to Win model. So much bad.Pros: If you're into that sort of thing this game has a large vibrant and diverse DC Universe based role playing community. There are no other redeeming values. Truly. None.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
20, 2014
												Let me save you some time. It's dull, and you are are severely handicapped not just content wise but power and money wise without a subscription. The combat is meh, most of the abilities don't really have that wow factor or that oomph feeling that everyone in other MMO's have a few of. Combat is largely just left-and right click mouse combos and a few abilities peppered in. The character creation is neat but has a lot more room for improvement - half the characters you see will have the same serious personality and stand like they have a stick up their butt. Some powers and weapons are limited by purchasing specific content or having a subscription, which I get, but POWER RINGS LOCKED? REALLY? NO GREEN LANTERN FOR YOU! And I know its game but if you want some degree of immersion in the universe, hope you don't mind all the generic MMO try-too-hard names your comrades will have - superman289, Batlord, XSupermangX sure don't seem to mind.The equivalent of dungeons are also extremely boring. While it was nice that they varied in group size, the ones I did needed zero communication at all - people round and punch stuff or hold E for a second.If you want to play as a villian hope you have a few friends who want to do it with you - for every 1 villian there seems to be about 5-10 heroes. I can't even recall one time villians won one of the nearby pvp events.The mentoring concept (in which what hero or villian you chose to teach you) could have been amazing - but instead it just changes the missions/quests you do while leveling. You could be reporting and fighting with batman, or being taught the tricks of the trade by Lex Luthor but NOOOOOOOPE go out into the city and do random stuff while I occaisonally talk on the radio.I will give it one high mark though - the styles tab. It keeps track of every style of gear piece you have looted and allows you to display that item instead of the one equipped without having to equip it. The best part is you can do it anytime even if you no longer own the items, and you can even lock the style so it never changes until you tell it to. IT IS GENIUS! I've seen other games do things similar, but usually, you still have to own the item, or if you equip a new piece over it you have to talk to someone to revisiualize it. It's like transmogging from WoW but without the lost bank space and gold cost.Overall it's dissapointing: The core concept of Thousands of people suddenly being given powers and becoming heroes of villians and why it happened, was good. The idea for a mentor was great. The idea that you get to create your own person and interact with villians and heroes in the DC universe? GOOOOOOOOOOOD.The problem is the execution is horrible. They tried to combine Arkham games combat with generic mmo combat, and the end result is neither part works well or feels fun. The character creation is a little too restrictive and having all the players in one region on one server results in crappy named characters (not even happy with my own for once) and missions contained in one small spot trying to be finished by 10-30 people. Fighting often feels slow and floaty. Many concepts such as the mentors and the hideouts/bases largely fall flat, and you may find yourself feeling that the way they implemented them was unnecessary. It took so many negative or meh things other mmo's did, and tried mixing it in with one or two good ideas.At the end of the day it's not worth it to me to invest any more time, or any money, into this game. It feels like one long slog where you don't feel any sense of achievement, the combat lacks impact and excitement, and the controls are kinda goofy at times. If you love DC comics or the stuff that comes out of them you might want to at least try it and form your own opinion - after all there is a free play model. But if you're just looking for an online game there are plenty out there better. If you're looking for a good DC game try the Batman Arkham games, or Injustice: Gods Among Us.

content:
0, 2016
												This is an utterly addictive game for a fan of DC Comics. I'm uncertain how non-fans might feel, but as a fangirl, I've really enjoyed playing in the world I've read about for so many years. I'm using a free account, which means I've been bumping up against the paywall, but despite the limitations, the game is still playable, just more challenging (which is a plus). The positives are many: Lots of in-jokes, winks, and nods for the long-time fans to enjoy. The game itself is fun, allowing you to create superhero characters with a good variety of powers. Leveling up through the first 30 levels is guided by missions that you must complete to advance to the next mission. Each one provides new challenges for learning your skills and powers. Once you reach level 30, the real game starts with a variety of daily missions available and plenty of different possible paths, from player-vs-player to group co-op play and even quite a few single player adventures. As a person who enjoys single player, I found the gameplay immersive and fun... although playing some scenarios solo is definitely a challenge. You learn how to draw enemies away from the crowd to take them on singly. This is definitely a game to play with a group. The adventures in which I've teamed up with others have been extremely fun.The negatives are mostly due to playing on a free account. Free accounts cannot sell items on the broker, have limited inventory and banking space, and the cash limit really makes it difficult to buy really nice gear. However, these are all challenges and working around them can actually make the game more fun. Although, considering the amount of time I've already put into the game and how much I enjoy it, I suspect I will eventually pay for an account.Other negatives: The game is prone to freezing and crashing, but luckily it happens rarely. I'm sure part of it is due to my lack of a proper gaming computer. Like any Massive Multiplaying Online game, there are downtimes. In fact, I'm writing this in a downtime, since I'd scheduled some time to play and the game is offline. For a complete newbie, the controls are not obvious and there are no simple guides to show people how to move and hit. Yeah, I bumped my first opponent a lot until I figured out how to use the keyboard and mouse together.In short, the positives outweigh the negatives for the most part. If you are a fan of DC Comics, this is definitely a game to try.

content:
er 30, 2014
												When DC announced the marriage of DC Universe Online, I think every single nerd on the planet immediately said to themselves, "This can go one of two ways; pretty damned awesome or the most excruciating experience invented since the bikini wax."  And lo and behold, we met the second most painful item to hit mankind.  Originally, the developing company hyped up the game, promising everything from customizable player housing, villian and hero PvP that would be well-balanced and enjoyable, as well as a relentless assault on the typical flavor of the week scenarios and power upgrades.  They promised scenarios and power types that have actually existed in the DC comic genre.  Out of all of their promises, they've fulfilled two.  In a ratio based item, that's 2:45.In general, that's bad business.  When they discovered that they were unable to or were expected to keep their promises, they quickly went the route of the current MMO genre; free to play.  Since then, the game has constantly had ill-repairs, downtime, unmet promises, and very, very low expectations.  It is just one step above Champions Online, save for the strange Mortal Combat type figurations for certain attack moves (down, down-right, right anyone?).  DC Universe actually has a storyline, which is impressive given its current state of affairs in-game.  Character customization is lacking.  The developing company (mainly their PR branch) continues to promise amazing new feats, outfits, and customization that will resurrect its game in a manner that would put an unnamed fellow from 2000 some years ago to shame.  Unfortunately, thus far, they've only been able to resurrect a continual decline in player data-base, as well as overall effectiveness.However, they still offer a plate of cookies and a strangely colored kool-aid.

content:
21, 2015
												The reason for not recommending this game is simple, the devs and the company behind. Let me elaborate around it.I originally bought this game on release for a set price and I subbed for a few months liking the game, listening to TotalBiscuits recommendation at the time. The game is a very different approach to the MMO we knew at the time. Brawling, leveling, discovering and exploring the cities and solo dungeons within it. I leveled my character to 50, going nature/rifles. But didn't find the armors at the end-game that appealing and dropped the game cuz there wasn't anything to do.But in 2012 the game accounts got migrated to ProSiebenSat, and we all had to migrate our accounts else all be lost, they sent me an email about this and so I did it. Still when I downloaded the game from Steam, it would still try to connect to the old account servers, at least I couldn't get it to work right out of the Steam-box.But I still played it from time to time, made some alts and confirmed that the game was still good. I bought a few DLCs, like the base and stuff, saw that the game had done some progress since launch.So I got my new computer and downloaded this game once again, through Steam. And when I tried logging on I got a message that said my account was banned. So I sent them a ticket about it, asking for my real account name(as it became differently at the time of ProSiebenSat migrating). But the answer I got was horrifying.They told me there was another migration FROM ProSiebenSat and back in 2014. And that the last chance of this migration was 31st of January 2015.I NEVER GOT AN EMAIL ABOUT THIS!(TLDR;) The results are, I don't have ANY characters, but they unbanned the account, and told me I had to start over.I don't have ANY DLCs, that I paid real money for.They didn't alert me for the migration(I have searched and searched for those emails they claim to have sent me).They suck as a company, (in b4 they're the next to take the throne after EA for worst company NA?)I thought I'd still give the game a chance. I logged in, made a Catwoman-like character. The results were STILL HORRIBLE: 1. She doesn't come with a whip, or any whip attacks(no the taser doesn't count). 2. She came with non-high heels(I had to choose my own boots to get the right look).3. She's standing like she's a monster(beast-like atttitude), even the one in-game doesn't stand like that!). So I'm leaving this game for good. UNINSTALLED, I'm over it..And I'm gonna be sceptical to all games released by Daybreak(old SOE) in the future, as they cannot be trusted, even with the migration they failed badly. First impressions are quite bad!

content:
, 2014
												For those out of the loop, this probably represents the last of the big old-style MMOs. Even though it was only released in 2011, there’s something about it that feels more tired than Bruce Wayne’s put upon butler. Indeed, there’s a grind to almost every mission, the graphics don’t exactly sparkle (even on new hardware), and how you choose to fight seems to have very little bearing on the outcome of battle. Speedy level progression and focus on all combat, all the time might prove tedious if you're someone who enjoys exploring new worlds for the thrill of mystery and discovery. The largely instanced, repeatable endgame content is fun, but it's not inviting enough to make it worth paying a monthly fee for it. But even if it doesn't provide enough new content to sustain you beyond a couple of weeks, DC Universe Online is generally entertaining, and comic book fans will be happy that the license was handled with care.Perhaps the best gameplay feature of DCUO is the design of its default UI layout and keybinds. Instead of the standard MMOG mechanic of "tab-target, auto-attack, fire-all-your-cooldowns-and-wait-for-refresh" that leaves you a slave to whack-a-mole style hotbuttons and timers, DCUO maps the entirety of your primary weapon set to a single button. Through a series of "clicks" and "holds," your avatar will execute different combinations of superpowered techniques that are the bread and butter of your life as a hero or villain. The additional powers you can use are yours to command at YOUR discretion, not the whim of a global cooldown, and you may find yourself going as long as an hour or two without needing to activate a single one. This combination of simplicity and freedom allow you to do something that has become less common in MMOGs - you can actually watch the action unfold instead of always having your eyes fixed to your hotbars. This also has allowed the DCUO devs to include clever boss fight mechanics that include a reliance on environmental awareness, since it's easier to see what's going on around you.

content:
, 2016
												How did this game survive when City of Heroes died out?I have played through the game three times now and completed the story as a Tech, Meta, and Magic character. But once you hit level 30 and complete the main story, there is nothing left to do except PVP, which unless you're shilling out the dollars (or whatever currency your country runs on), you're pretty much guaranteed to lose.The power selection is also EXTREMELY limited compared to other super hero games like City of Heroes, or Champions Online. Each power set is divided up into two types which as far as I can tell boil down to DPS vs Crowd Control.Their website hasn't been updated since War of the Light, so I'm going to tell you which power sets are available in the game as of the time of writing this. The Power Sets for those who aren't paying a subscription are Fire, Ice, Gadgets, Mental, Nature, and Sorcery.The powers sets for those who do pay a subscription includes the previons ones, as well as Light (green / yellow rings), Rage (red ring), Earth, Lightning, Quantum (time / space),  Blessed / Cursed (good and evil magic), and Munitions (lots of guns).They also plan to include additional paid for powers such as Water and Serums.Unfortunately these new power sets contribute nothing to the game's replay value. The story is the same regardless, and once again, there's nothing to do except PVP once you complete it.The game has also begun to die out. When I first starting playing the game, the streets were filled with heroes and villains. When I tried to do a PVP server, I could scarcely go on a mission without being dog piled by the enemy team. Now the game is mostly deserted on both PVP and PVE servers. I think I found maybe 2 or 3 enemies that were still hunting players on PVP servers, but that's it.The only travel powers that are any fun is Speed Force and Acrobatics. Flight and the hover discs are a joke, nobody seems to like them. Probably because at a certain level, you can get a jet booster with Acrobatics that allows you to get around just as easily as flight, and in a much faster method. That's right, FLIGHT is the slowest travel power in the game!The game also lacks a character diversity concept such as races. I get that the story is that you were a human that inherited super powers, but they could have at least included a racial template such as Thanagarian, Kryptonian, Martian, Atlantean, Cyborg, Robot, and so on. You can get skins for some of these races, and you can get similar powers, but these are purely cosmetic and don't affect your strengths and weaknesses at all.DC Universe Online is a super hero game that falls short when compared to many other games of its genre. It is not worth the money they want you to pump into it, and is already dying as it is. The game should be allowed to go out with whatever dignity it has left, rather than trying to resuscitate it.

content:
ber 7, 2015
												Jogo simplesmente sensacional! O que posso dizer de um jogo como este, onde eu posso criar o meu próprio Super-Herói ou me inspirar nos que eu assistia e lia quando criança? Poxa, encontrei esse jogo tarde de mais eu acho, gostaria de ter o conhecido mais cedo, porque cara, que joguinho pra viciar. Os gráficos para um MMO são lindos, e os poderes que se pode ter também. As quests são em geral fáceis, mas as dungeons são muito ♥♥♥♥! Proporcionando ao jogador uma dificuldade razoável, onde várias vezes você vai morrer, até você achar o ponto fraco do inimigo e bater lá. O jogo tem um sistema de cash e premium member, ou Legendary, mas não muda em nada o gameplay, só da ao jogador vantagens de ter TODAS as DLCs do jogo de graça e a opção de criar uma Liga, e o preço do membro mensal não chega a ser tão caro, R$23,99, sendo que nos EUA são U$14,99, ou seja, estamos saindo com lucro, pois a mensalidade seria quase R$60,00. Mas enfim, não estou dizendo para você pagar mensalmente, você pode simplesmente comprar as DLCs e viver sua vida.   A busca pelo level 30 é complicada, demora bastante para você upar, tendo que fazer duas ou até mesmo 3 missões para upar metade do level, mas é assim mesmo, se você quer facilidade vai jogar Minecraft.    Enfim pessoal, jogo 100% recomendado, se você gosta do universo DC, você vai amar esse jogo, os gráficos são lindos, a jogabilidade quase que perfeita, a história é boa, e a dublagem em inglês sensacional.

content:
11, 2013
												Hands down one of the best MMORPG's I've ever played. If you love DC you will love this game. If not, you will get to know all of the heroes and villians to an extent and even come across ones you've never even seen or heard of. I have. Since this was made for the systems, it plays almost exactly like a combat game...online. The only difference is (big surprise) you get skills and powers that you need to assign to numbers. The graphics are well done, the customization of your hero/villain is in depth and unlike any other MMO I've ever played (which is quite a lot), you can customize your characters look in game and still keep the equipped gear on your character. It's fun to mix and match powers as well! Just a friendly warning to you newbies out there...if you join the PvP server you will want to watch out since you can be killed anywhere outside of buildings. If the high levels bother you too much you can go to 'The Watchtower' or 'Hall of Doom' depending on whether you make a hero or villain, and go to a 'phase shifter'. This will allow you to switch between PvP and PvE. As much as I'd love to go on and on about the game...this is already quite a review. I honestly have nothing negative to say. 10/10 -Frillin

content:
, 2015
												Don't let my time on record fool you, I have sunk thousands of hours and dollars into this game since it launched on PS3. At one time I considered DCUO my favorite game of all time and I met some really cool people through it. The game had unlimited potential with an original combat system and the DC comics backing that had me pumped to be apart of it from the start and excited for the future. Unfortunately, over the last few years the devs have consistently made changes that have hurt the game and player base. It's obvious to me that the game is now just an ultimate cash grab for every single thing they implement. Bugs take years to get fixed unless they take money out of their pockets. New added powers come out completely overpowered so everyone pays to switch to them and then a month or so later get nerfed into the ground so you need to switch in order to stay competitive. There is zero benefit to being a player who puts a lot of money into the game. You can now pay to own powers at $5 each, but why is it that if I "own" the powerset on the game that I still have to pay $10 to change to the power on my hero/villain? The last straw for me was them implementing "stat flattening" or "stat clamping" whatever you/ they want to call it. I played this game to make my character stronger and feel like a growing superhero among other superheroes, not to get to a certain level and then get weaker for older content! I would love for the game to start making better steps and entice me to come back, but I fear things are just going to get worse because of the greed of the developers.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
y 29, 2014
												OverviewTLDR: If you don't plan to invest more than 8 hours a day for a few months into this game, don't bother getting the DLC or any other product that requires money. It's a very small great game wrapped in a much larger awful game. It is not casual friendly after level 30.After having played this game an absurd amount of time for a casual gamer (which I measure by comparing it to the amount of time I spend playing any other game, which is about 4-6 hours a day, depending on how entertaining it is), I found myself enjoying it quite a bit. I got a few characters to level 30 and started to play some of the beginning endgame content to come to a startling realization.For the "casual" gamer, DCUO is a huge waste of time. What do I mean by "casual" gamer? I mean a person who enjoys a few hours of game play a day in between other responsibilities and games you enjoy. This game has a lot of fun and attractive elements. It aged well for a game that has been around since 2011. It is well set into the DC universe (no pun intended) and has all of the characters you've come to enjoy. The character creation and powers are entertaining and give you many ways to configure your appearance and show off some creativity. Combat will draw you in and the storylines are very fun, even after multiple playthroughs. The voice acting for the heroes and villains are also extremely well performed and makes you feel like a part of their world. Getting to level 30 is very enjoyable. It was for these reasons that I bought the DLC. I wanted more of this. It turns out that this was the end of all the fun was going to have with this game.Once you hit level 30 the "real" game begins. And by real, I mean the un-fun grinding of worthless items to afford 1/10th of one percent of the actual gear you will need to actually make mission progress. Most MMO games are like this... it gets to a point where it stops becoming a roleplaying superhero game and starts being "Number Watcher: The Game." One finds themselves needing to raise one's stats to an arbitrary level before one may progress further. This becomes the norm, completely independent of any kind of roleplaying element.This is not helped at all by the other major sin of this game which is that the descriptions for items you buy/receive are useless and misleading. I have many examples of misleading object listings, but here are a few. When trying to trade with other players, it will tell you that a subscription is necessary to enable trading of items and money. This is misleading, since it implies you may NOT trade items and money without a subscription when, in fact, you can trade items. Yes, you need a subscription to trade in-game cash, but the items, provided they are not locked to an account, may be traded as you like.Another example is that it is not particularly clear what marketplace items can be traded to other players. One may not trade armories (a new addition to the game) that have been purchased nor can one trade "station cash" to other players. You also cannot buy DLC with station cash. Sony removed this ability after losing a significant amount of money, meaning you're going to have to buy it direct from steam or some other process. The marketplace locations, however, do not tell you this. They are marked with "buy now" buttons which take you to the website where you can purchase them directly. Why are the DLC in the shop at all if you can't buy them with station cash? This has led a number of people to purchase station cash only to be disappointed in finding that they had made an expensive mistake. Further examples? The "end-game" armor I mentioned earlier is not well marked. Certain armors are meant to improve PvE rating and other improve PvP ratings. While this is an important distinction, neither armor is marked as exclusively useful for one or the other. You have to find this out on your own or consult the DCUO wiki.Some of the end-game missions that they give you off the bat are meant for multiple people. It is true that Calculator tells you this, but the missions themselves are not clearly marked like the on-duty counterparts. Or you can consult the DCUO Wiki. You can also make items and objects that can be used in combat using "exobite data." This is a significant portion of the armor crafting process. How do you accomplish this? They don't tell you it. You need to ask or consult the wiki.For most problems, one has to frequently indulge the DCUO wiki for information on what terms or requirements are needed and they are not always clear. The forums are full of people asking (if not begging) for clarification on what needs doing or what certain descriptions mean. The Stats and power descriptions are also very poorly done and do not fully explain what the powers do in a clear and understandable way. Perhaps one of the biggest problems with unclear descriptions is the way that the DLC advertise new missions and the like for your character. What they do NOT tell you is that in order to actually use most of the PvE content, you need to have a high "combat rating". What is the "combat rating" you ask? The wiki is the place to go for the answers, but even then, I found myself asking people "How do I start the War of the Light DLC?" only to be told I need a combat rating of 84 or, roughly, tier 4 armor.  The more formidable your armor, the higher your rating.To receive tiered armor, you must play missions to achieved "Marks of valor" or "marks of triumph" or whatever other marks are required to purchase the desired armor. The better the armor, the higher your combat rating. It requires a combat rating of 84 to use the Tier 5 armor, so one assumes one needs a complete set of Tier 4 armor to achieve this goal. To accomplish this, it requires an endless amount of grinding missions within a given tier from the "on duty" menu to farm the marks to get the armor to get the missions from the DLCIf you just beat the game and are now level 30? That's likely months away from the completion of the "end game." When I made this realization, all desire to continue playing left my body, along with any sense of fun and enjoyment. I'd have to make this game my job in order to see the DLC I just purchased anytime soon.  These requirements are not described anywhere on the DLC's purchase page. I would not have spent a single cent if there had been even one cautionary word relating to "combat ratings" needing to be obtained in order to use the majority of the features contained within the DLC. This game is not for the casual player. It is meant for someone with a lot of free time and money to spend and little else to do. Maybe after a year or so, a casual player might be able to make it to a high enough level to use the DLC, but those people will likely be weeded out by the dedicated grinders who make it their job to keep casuals out of major battle groups for the sake of improving the odds of success over teaching people who have not made this game their religion.There are MMOs that are friendlier to new and casual players. That said, play this game. Its free. Play it to level 30 and have fun. After that, drop it like a bad habit. If you're a hard core MMORPG player, then you'll probably like all the PVP stuff and the high level gear that you can lord over other players. I wouldn't know because I'm not one of those.

content:
, 2016
												How did this game survive when City of Heroes died out?I have played through the game three times now and completed the story as a Tech, Meta, and Magic character. But once you hit level 30 and complete the main story, there is nothing left to do except PVP, which unless you're shilling out the dollars (or whatever currency your country runs on), you're pretty much guaranteed to lose.The power selection is also EXTREMELY limited compared to other super hero games like City of Heroes, or Champions Online. Each power set is divided up into two types which as far as I can tell boil down to DPS vs Crowd Control.Their website hasn't been updated since War of the Light, so I'm going to tell you which power sets are available in the game as of the time of writing this. The Power Sets for those who aren't paying a subscription are Fire, Ice, Gadgets, Mental, Nature, and Sorcery.The powers sets for those who do pay a subscription includes the previons ones, as well as Light (green / yellow rings), Rage (red ring), Earth, Lightning, Quantum (time / space),  Blessed / Cursed (good and evil magic), and Munitions (lots of guns).They also plan to include additional paid for powers such as Water and Serums.Unfortunately these new power sets contribute nothing to the game's replay value. The story is the same regardless, and once again, there's nothing to do except PVP once you complete it.The game has also begun to die out. When I first starting playing the game, the streets were filled with heroes and villains. When I tried to do a PVP server, I could scarcely go on a mission without being dog piled by the enemy team. Now the game is mostly deserted on both PVP and PVE servers. I think I found maybe 2 or 3 enemies that were still hunting players on PVP servers, but that's it.The only travel powers that are any fun is Speed Force and Acrobatics. Flight and the hover discs are a joke, nobody seems to like them. Probably because at a certain level, you can get a jet booster with Acrobatics that allows you to get around just as easily as flight, and in a much faster method. That's right, FLIGHT is the slowest travel power in the game!The game also lacks a character diversity concept such as races. I get that the story is that you were a human that inherited super powers, but they could have at least included a racial template such as Thanagarian, Kryptonian, Martian, Atlantean, Cyborg, Robot, and so on. You can get skins for some of these races, and you can get similar powers, but these are purely cosmetic and don't affect your strengths and weaknesses at all.DC Universe Online is a super hero game that falls short when compared to many other games of its genre. It is not worth the money they want you to pump into it, and is already dying as it is. The game should be allowed to go out with whatever dignity it has left, rather than trying to resuscitate it.

content:
, 2016
												Fun but so ♥♥♥♥ing freemium its not even free to play. Its just free to download. Will not reccomend until they get rid of these ♥♥♥♥ing paywalls. To give an example to those considering playing this game, you literally have to pay to join the server quicker, otherwise you wait in a giant que. Over 8 of the power sets, all of them the coolest ones (default ones are ♥♥♥♥) are premium, as well as a weapon, a movement style, all the cool episodes, and even the ability to have more than 1500 ♥♥♥♥ing cash. The gameplay is breathtakingly fun and I love the game, but this DLC whoring and freemium ♥♥♥♥ is overboard. If you are restrained enough not to spend money, play this game, it is extremely fun, but be careful of the money whoring.
